body.p: RabbitMQ clusters do not tolerate network partitions well. If you are thinking of clustering across a WAN, don't. You should use federation or the shovel instead.
However, sometimes accidents happen. This page documents how to detect network partitions, some of the bad effects that may happen during partitions, and how to recover from them.

RabbitMQ stores information about queues, exchanges, bindings etc in Erlang's distributed database, Mnesia. Many of the details of what happens around network partitions are related to Mnesia's behaviour.

Mnesia will typically determine that a node is down if another node is unable to contact it for a minute or so (see the section on net_ticktime below). If two nodes come back into contact, both having thought the other is down, Mnesia will determine that a partition has occured. This will be written to the RabbitMQ log in a form like:
RabbitMQ nodes will record whether this event has ever occured while the node is up, and expose this information through rabbitmqctl cluster_status and the management plugin.
rabbitmqctl cluster_status will normally show an empty list for partitions:
body.pre: # rabbitmqctl cluster_status Cluster status of node rabbit@smacmullen ... [{nodes,[{disc,[hare@smacmullen,rabbit@smacmullen]}]}, {running_nodes,[rabbit@smacmullen,hare@smacmullen]}, {partitions,[]}] ...done.
body.p: However, if a network partition has occured then information about partitions will appear there:
body.pre: # rabbitmqctl cluster_status Cluster status of node rabbit@smacmullen ... [{nodes,[{disc,[hare@smacmullen,rabbit@smacmullen]}]}, {running_nodes,[rabbit@smacmullen,hare@smacmullen]}, {partitions,[{rabbit@smacmullen,[hare@smacmullen]}, {hare@smacmullen,[rabbit@smacmullen]}]}] ...done.
body.p: The management plugin API will return partition information for each node under partitions in /api/nodes. The management plugin UI will show a large red warning on the overview page if a partition has occured.

While a network partition is in place, the two (or more!) sides of the cluster can evolve independently, with both sides thinking the other has crashed. Queues, bindings, exchanges can be created or deleted separately. Mirrored queues which are split across the partition will end up with one master on each side of the partition, again with both sides acting independently. Other undefined and weird behaviour may occur.

p.b: It is important to understand that when network connectivity is restored, this state of affairs persists. The cluster will continue to act in this way until you take action to fix it.

body.p: To recover from a network partition, first choose one partition which you trust the most. This partition will become the authority for the state of Mnesia to use; any changes which have occured on other partitions will be lost.
Stop all nodes in the other partitions, then start them all up again. When they rejoin the cluster they will restore state from the trusted partition.
Finally, you should also restart all the nodes in the trusted partition to clear the warning.
The initial determination that a node is down is made by the Erlang virtual machine. This is controlled by the net_ticktime parameter to the kernel application, documented here.
It is possible that you may want to increase the net_ticktime value to cover up short-lived network outages. You could do so with a configuration file looking like:
which would increase the ticktime from 60 seconds to 120 seconds.
Conversely, you may wish to decrease the value in order to detect network outages more promptly.

But be aware that there is no free lunch here: by increasing the ticktime you also increase the length of time that RabbitMQ may be unresponsive, waiting for a reply from a cluster node which has gone down or lost connectivity. Conversely, decreasing the ticktime can result in nodes being detected as dead when in fact they are still alive and reachable but perhaps busy. Adjusting the net_ticktime is not a general solution to the problem of network partitions.

An alternative approach is to tell RabbitMQ to use pause-minority mode. In this mode RabbitMQ will choose partition tolerance over availability from the CAP theorem, by automatically pausing cluster nodes which determine themselves to be in a minority after seeing other nodes go down. This ensures that in the event of a network partition, at most the nodes in a single partition will continue to run.

The Erlang VM on the paused nodes will continue running but the nodes will not listen on any ports or do any other work. They will check once per second to see if the rest of the cluster has reappeared, and start up again if it has.

Note that nodes will not enter the paused state at startup, even if they are in a minority then. It is expected that any such minority at startup is due to the rest of the cluster not having been started yet.
You can enable pause-minority mode by setting the configuration parameter cluster_partition_handling to pause_minority for the rabbit application in your configuration file.

Note that RabbitMQ will pause nodes which are not in a strict majority of the cluster - i.e. greater than 50%. It is therefore not a good idea to enable pause-minority mode on a cluster of two nodes since in the event of a network partition or node failure, both nodes will pause. However, pause_minority mode is likely to be safer than ignore mode for clusters of more than two nodes, especially if the most likely form of network partition is that a single minority of nodes drops off the network.
